pull out.translation[0].definitions[0].d: to drive onto a road from another road or from where you have stopped
pull out.translation[0].definitions[0].e: Don’t pull out! There’s something coming.
pull out.translation[0].definitions[1].d: to drive over to a different part of the road in order to get past a vehicle in front of you
pull out.translation[0].definitions[1].e: I pulled out to overtake a bus.
pull out.translation[0].definitions[2].d: if a train pulls out, it leaves a station
pull out.translation[0].definitions[3].d: to stop doing or being involved in something, or to make someone do this
pull out.translation[0].definitions[3].e: McDermott pulled out with an injury at the last minute.
They are trying to pull out of the agreement.
He threatened to pull his son out of the team.
pull out.translation[0].definitions[4].d: to get out of a bad situation or dangerous place, or to make someone or something do this
pull out.translation[0].definitions[4].e: Jim saw that the firm was going to be ruined, so he pulled out.
Most of the troops have been pulled out.
when the country was still pulling out of a recession
pull out.translation[1].definitions[0].d: the act of an army, business etc leaving a particular place
pull out.translation[1].definitions[0].e: The pull-out of troops will begin soon.
pull out.translation[1].definitions[1].d: part of a book or magazine that is designed to be removed and read separately
pull out.translation[2].definitions[0].d: to get out of an agreement, deal, or difficult situation so that you are no longer taking part in it
pull out.translation[2].definitions[0].e: If the project costs continue to rise, we may be forced to pull out.
Catalogue shopping group Argos is pulling out of its furniture store venture because it sees no prospect of improved trading conditions.
